text: I asked the storytellers to answer the
question I actually was it was in the
formative stages when I asked this first
storyteller I said what what is right I
didn't say who was right I said what is
right and his answer was and I quote if
you take away everything that's left
then what's left is right
please welcome Frank we'll check
in 15 minutes Frank will check will be
coming to the stage but in the meantime
Frank will check
hi science fans in the late spring of
1999 I got a phone call from Scientific
American a man named Walter Wagner who I
later learned was a banana farmer in
Hawaii was worried about black holes
more specifically he was worrying about
the accelerator that was going to start
operating on Long Island Brookhaven lab
that that accelerator would produce
little black holes that would then start
swallowing things and and then swallow
the world so they asked me to write a
reply to mr. Wagner why me
well the point of this accelerator was
to study what happens when you collide
very very fast-moving energetic atomic
nuclei with each other and the point of
the study was mostly largely to test my
theories about the existence of gluons
and the properties of quarks that would
tell you we're supposed to tell you what
happens in these collisions that in this
collision you produce a fireball of
gluons and quarks and antiquarks you'd
produce something that we think the
early universe looked like so people
were making models of what the early
universe the very early universe looked
like based on my theories but the
theories had never been tested directly
and this is what was gonna happen at
Brookhaven so I was supposed to be an
authority on what was happening in these
collisions and when Scientific American
called the Brookhaven press office the
press office referred them to me if
everything went well and these theories
were verified I would be a hero probably
gonna know about prize for it so I want
it to be the note I want it to be the
go-to guy and so I thought I really had
to write this reply and I said yes so I
started writing this reply and I
explained that gravity between little
things like atomic nuclei is very feeble
so that you really couldn't produce a
black hole at Brookhaven and even if you
did the black hole that you produced
would be really really small it would be
smaller than an atom even smaller than
an atomic nucleus and really really
small and it wouldn't be the gaping maw
that you see in Disney films it was
really tiny thing very very feeble
gravity comes out of it it really
wouldn't be very good at sucking up
matter or long island or the world and
even if it did
when you took into account quantum
mechanics as Stephen Hawking taught us
in his greatest work these black hole
this like tiny black claw would be
unstable with decay quickly before it
could do much eating and even if you
didn't believe all that there was the
fact that every day somewhere on earth
several times in fact in different
places on the earth collisions between
cosmic rays raining down on the earth
and the atmosphere or earth itself with
as much energy as was going to be
produced in the collisions at this
accelerator were happening and this had
been going on for billions of years and
the earth was still here
so I thought that was a pretty
convincing reply altogether but it was
also obvious and kind of trivial that I
was kind of embarrassed to put my name
to this I mean any fool could have done
that analysis and showed that mr. Wagner
had nothing to worry about but I was
supposed to be brilliant and a potential
Nobel Prize winner so I thought I should
produce something more compelling and
unique and original so I decided to
spice it up
now now there is actually a much more
plausible way that you could imagine an
accelerator destroying the earth and
this is something called strangelets
some otherwise respectable physicists
had speculated about the possibility
that you could have an alternative way
of corks arranging themselves the way
they ordinarily do to the way they do in
the matter that we know about and are
comfortable with and are made out of
that there would be this alternative
form in which they were much more dense
this is called strange matter because
the strange matter would also contain a
lot of strange quarks and little chunks
of strange matter are called strangelets
so you can imagine producing strangelets
at an accelerator like the Brookhaven
accelerator and that was much more
serious and I was very proud that I had
produced a more interesting reply
but well I went on to analyze to discuss
in more detail the physics of these
strangelets and why really when you
thought about it more deeply
there was no genuine possibility of
producing strangelets which would grow
at at Brookhaven I should say if you
want to visualize strangelets think of
ice 9 Kurt Vonnegut's ice 9 which is a
form of water a different state of water
that could crystallize and then swallow
the oceans because the water would like
to crystallize around a little bit of
ice 9 or think of prion diseases in
inside brains where you have little
crystals of an abnormal of brain protein
and if you have a little crystal the
rest of the brain protein of that kind
will start to crystallize around it and
your brain kind of solidifies and you
get kuru you get all silly and die so
strangelets are like that they're like
ice 9 for water or like prions for brain
proteins but they would they would do
the job for nuclear matter of all kinds
so if you produced a strangelet that did
that it would be a bad thing
definitely so i discussed all that but
then i went on to discuss that many
barriers to that it could it wouldn't
happen at Brookhaven and I concluded of
course with the conclusive argument from
cosmic rays that if it was gonna happen
it would have happened already so it was
all very elegant and I now was happy
proud to sign my name
this piece but when I sent it to
Scientific American they were not
pleased or they because what I had
produced was much too long it was more
like an article than a reply to the
letter it was much much longer than the
letter itself that started it so they
said well you know we only have limited
space for letters we're gonna have to
make some cuts okay and well time passed
and they made some cuts the cuts were
not exactly surgical unless by surgery
you mean amputation of limbs and when
they sent me the stump
that was left I was getting ready to
pack up and leave from my summer
seclusion up in New Hampshire and I
didn't want to get involved in fighting
a losing battle so I just glanced at it
and said sure
okay go ahead hell with you and so I
went to New Hampshire and spent several
idyllic weeks lovely weeks swimming and
thinking and writing and reading really
lovely until one day my brother-in-law
shows up riding his motorcycle and seems
rather frantic says you've got to call
Princeton I got a message from your
secretary you've got a call it's an
emergent it's really important okay well
what you should know is that the reason
he had to be delivering this message is
that when I said secluded I mean
secluded we didn't have telephone we
didn't certainly didn't have internet it
at that time we had nothing and in fact
the nearest phone was five miles away it
was a payphone so to get back to
Princeton and respond I had to drive
five miles down to the pay phone which I
did and when I called up my secretary
Margaret she was really excited she was
this was the most excited I've ever
heard Margaret before or since
and she said we've got an emergency a
lot of people want to talk to you and
she told me what had happened what had
happened was that on July 18th the
Sunday Times of London had a banner
headline all in capitals that said the
final experiment question mark and
underneath it was this really lurid
picture of a fireball obviously from a
nuclear explosion and the mushroom cloud
I mean the worst possible catastrophe
you can imagine and the article was
quoting me quoting very selectively from
my article from my reply to mr. Wagner
that in such a way as to suggest that I
was endorsing the idea that this
accelerator really would maybe do the
ultimate experiment and destroy Long
Island and then the world
so there were many journalists then who
picked up on this story they wanted to
interview me and I also had a call from
the management of Brookhaven laboratory
and they really wanted to talk to me so
so I called up Brookhaven or actually
yeah I called up Brookhaven and but they
said the directors busy we'll call you
back so I gave him number of this pay
phone and he called me back about 10
minutes later and he said we have a
problem we're getting inquiries from our
congressmen and from governor from
senator de Matos office some of you may
remember a senator Alphonse D'Amato he
was very interested in this and you've
really caused a problem here Frank
and you're gonna you're really gonna
have to talk to all these journalists
and it gave me a list of 20 journalists
that I had to talk to and you're gonna
have to reassure people and get this
situation under control tell them the
truth so that so that the laboratory can
go ahead and do the experiments that you
want it done so he was very nice about
it but clearly the message was that you
really up guy and now you made a
mess and you'd better clean it up okay
so so I had this list of 20 journalists
that I had to get in contact with I
started to work on it
there were big problems because the only
way I could reach them was through this
pay phone and the pay phone was shared
with some really scary-looking truckers
not very patient so I had to kind of
make schedule I also had to ask the
people to call me because they didn't
have enough quarters for all these
international calls and so I spent two
weeks top sorry two days it seemed like
two weeks two full days plus another
half day talking 1 an hour or so to
these journalists most of whom didn't
speak English very well
I used hand gestures almost all of whose
knowledge of science was extremely
tenuous and because of that I was able
to reassure them and take the tempest
down so but I really suffered for
science that time just between us it was
kind of fun as especially in retrospect
the next time I suffered for science was
October 3rd 2004 when I got another
phone call what happened was I knew that
Nobel Prize was going to be announced
that day at 6 a.m. Eastern Time so I
wasn't able to sleep but at 5 a.m. I
looked at the clock and said well ok you
might as well take a shower just in case
you'll be ready
then at 5:11 my wife came in with the
telephone our mobile phone and said
there's a lady on the phone from Sweden
says she wants to talk to you and I
didn't know that they told you you win
the Nobel Prize before they make the
official announcement and that was it
I also didn't know what the phone
conversation would be like I thought it
would be congratulations you've won the
Nobel Prize goodbye
mm-hmm but it wasn't that way at all and
I get well I could tell you a lot about
it but to make a long story short I got
all kinds of instructions
starting with shut up until 6 o'clock
when the official announcement comes
congratulations from friends can talk to
the chairman of this committee and the
president of that Academy and so and it
all took 20 minutes or so
probably longer the whole time I was
stark completely naked and dripping wet
so that was the other time I suffered
for science
